title: Integrating High-Performance Computing with Electron Microscopy for Scientific Insights
content: With the advancement of efficient algorithms and improvements in electron microscopy, there is a potential to employ theoretical models in guiding and conducting experiments to extract materials physics from both domains concurrently. The use of deep learning (DL) models enables the extraction of atomic-level features from image data, seamlessly integrating them into simulation environments. Nevertheless, there are challenges in orchestrating an autonomous instrument-computing ecosystem, addressing issues related to deployment infrastructure and the exploration of novel physics. This process also requires refining parameters in both the experimental and theoretical realms, establishing a continuous feedback loop. Key challenges include addressing instrument specificity, managing implementation complexity, and handling information transferability, particularly considering the fundamentally different latencies [1-5] of imaging and simulations.
